newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS - AT&T says no plans for Australia local calls.
newsitem.headline: RTRS - AT&T says no plans for Australia local calls.

text.p: U.S. telephone giant AT&T Corp has no plans to enter Australia's local telephone call market when the market is fully deregulated next July 1, AT&T president Asia Pacific John Legere said.

Legere, who is attending a APEC telecommunications ministers meeting here, said AT&T has an alliance with Telstra Corp for the provision of the state-owned group's long distance calls, and that it would monitor the deregulation process in Australia.
"As the market liberalises, we will look at the opportunities," Legere told Reuters in an interview after he gave a speech to the APEC conference on Wednesday.
"We will look at the impact on our relationships and just watch the evolving situation and see if it provides opportunities for us," Legere said.
"Nothing is planned at this time. Australia is a very important market for us to serve our global customers," he said.
Australian telecommunications minister Richard Alston said at the conference the government would be releasing its 1997 telecommunications deregulation plan in the next few weeks.
State-owned Telstra Corp had a monopoly on Australia's local call market until pay tv and telecommunications group Optus Communications started its local telephone services in June.
The government plans to sell one-third of Telstra as part of the liberalisation of Australia's telecommunications market.
